ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much in ASL this semester! I learned lots of new vocabulary, as always, but I also learned more about Deaf culture and more about how to be conversational. I feel so much more confident in ASL now than I did at the beginning of the semester.
I continued to develop my signing abilities and knowledge of Deaf culture.
I learned a lot about ASL and Deaf culture.
I learned so much about culture and language. Great class.
Became very proficient in ASL by the end of ASL 3.

I improved my ASL a lot and even learned something deeper than ASL about how people communicate. Also Prof Fisher's comedy skills were 10/10 so I learned more about how to be funny without saying anything out loud.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Andrew's teaching, definitely. He's hilarious and makes learning fun with games and his general charisma. Journal entries become more work in this class, but I the addition of signing our own writing as a weekly assignment. 
Weaknesses: None. I love ASL at Yale!

The course is designed very well! I like the mostly in-person, one day remote format. Perhaps some attention could be paid to discussing common errors people make in their signing / giving more individualized feedback on a regular basis.
Strenghts: interesting, engaging, very caring professor

Andrew (and all of the other ASL professors) are so kind and engaging. Absolutely loved being in this class. Looked forward to it everyday. If you put effort into this class you are guaranteed to do well. They want to see you trying your best.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! I'd recommend anyone coming out of ASL 2 to take ASL 3. It's a fantastic course and you really learn so much more. I only took L3 so I could finish my language requirement, and now I'm planning on taking L4 and L5 because L3 really made the language click with me.
Yes! The Yale ASL program is very strongthe teachers truly care about their students as learners and as people.
Yes! Take ASL as your language. The department is fantastic and all of the professors are great.
